tit.e: Tenpo-tsuho (a coin that circulated in Japan during the end of Edo period and Meiji period)

sen.j: 天保通宝（てんぽつうほう）とは、江戸時代末期から明治にかけての日本で流通した銭貨。
sen.e: Tenpo-tsuho coins were coins that circulated in Japan during the end of the Edo period and Meiji period.
Tenpo-tsuho coins were coins that circulated in Japan during the end of the Edo period and Meiji period.
Tenpo-tsuho (a coin first minted in Tenpo era [1830 to 1843]) was a coin that circulated in Japan during the end of the Edo period and Meiji period.

sen.j: 天保銭（てんぽうせん）ともいう。
sen.e: It is also called Tenpo sen coins.
They were also known as Tenpo sen coins.
It was also known as Tenpo sen coins.

sen.j: 形状は、小判を意識した楕円形で、中心部に正方形の穴が開けられ、表面には「天保通寳」、裏面には「當百」と表記され、金座後藤家の花押が鋳込まれている。
sen.e: The coin has an ellipse shape that resembles koban (former Japanese oval coin) and has a square hole in the center. It is written "天保通寳 (Tenpotsusai)" on its head and "當百 (Tohyaku)"on its tail; also, Kao (written seal mark) of the Goto family, a kinza is casted on it.

The coin has an elliptical shape that resembled koban (former Japanese oval coin) and had a square hole in the center. "天保通寳 (Tenpotsusai)" was written on its head and "當百 (Tohyaku)"on its tail; also, Kao (written seal mark) of the Goto family, a kinza was casted on it.

The coin had an elliptical shape that resembled koban (former Japanese oval coin), having a square hole in the center, of which Chinese characters '天保通寳' (Tenpo-tsuho) was written on the front, '當百' (Tohyaku; referring that 1 Tenpo-tsuho was equivalent to 100 mon [a unit of currency]) and Kao (written seal mark) of the Goto family, kin-za (an organization in charge of casting and appraising of gold during the Edo period) on the back.

sen.j: 銅製で、重量は5.5匁（約20.6グラム）。
sen.e: It was made of copper and weighed (about 20.6 grams)
It was made of copper and weighed (about 20.6 grams)
It was made of copper and weighed 5.5 monme (about 20.6 grams).

sen.j: 天保6年（1835年）に創鋳された。
sen.e: It was issued in 1835.
It was issued in 1835.
It was minted in 1835.

sen.j: 貨幣価値は100文 (通貨単位)とされたが、実際には80文で通用した。
sen.e: Its currency value was fixed to 100 mon (currency unit), but in reality, it was passable as 80 mon.
Its currency value was fixed to 100 mon (currency unit), but in reality, it was passable as 80 mon.
Its currency value was fixed to 100 mon, but in reality, it was passable as 80 mon.
sen.cmt: 前出補足を削除しました。

sen.j: いずれにしても質量的に額面（寛永通宝100枚分）の価値は全くない貨幣で、経済に混乱を起こし偽造も相次いだという。
sen.e: As it was not worth its face value (100 Kanei tsuho coins) at all in terms of weight, it brought about economic confusion and forging became common.
As it was not worth its face value (100 Kanei tsuho coins) at all in terms of weight, it brought about economic confusion and forging became common.
As it was not worth its face value (100 Kanei-tsuho [coins first minted in 1636 of Kanrei era]) at all in terms of weight, it brought about economic confusion and forging became common.

sen.j: 明治維新後も流通したが、明治24年（1891年）12月31日を最後に正式に通用停止となった。
sen.e: Although it circulated even after the Meiji restoration, it was finally officially forbidden on December 31, 1891.
Although it circulated even after the Meiji restoration, it was finally officially forbidden on December 31, 1891.
Although it circulated even after the Meiji Restoration, it was officially forbidden to be used on December 31, 1891.

sen.j: 明治以後、陸軍大学校卒業者が付けた徽章が天保通宝に似ていた事から「天保銭組」と称せられた。
sen.e: After the Meiji period, as the badge that Rikugun Daigakko (the Army War College) graduates wore resembled Tenpo tsuho, it came to be called "Tenpo sen gumi (team)."
After the Meiji period, as the badge that Rikugun Daigakko (the Army War College) graduates wore resembled Tenpo tsuho, it came to be called "Tenpo sen gumi (team)."
After the Meiji period, as the badge that Rikugun Daigakko (the Army War College) graduates wore resembled the Tenpo-tsuho, they came to be called 'Tenpo sen gumi' (team of Tenpo-tsuho).

sen.j: その一方で、新通貨制度では天保通宝一枚＝8厘（寛永通宝一枚＝1厘）と換算されたために、新時代に乗り遅れた人やそれに適応するだけの才覚の足りない人を揶揄して「天保銭」と呼ぶ事もあったという。
sen.e: On the other hand, as one Tenpo-tsuho coin was converted as 8 rin (one Kanein-tsuho coin = 1 rin) in the new monetary system, it is said that people who were way behind the times or people who did not have ability to do so were sometimes called "Tenpo sen."

On the other hand, as one Tenpo-tsuho coin was converted as 8 rin (one Kanein-tsuho coin = 1 rin) in the new monetary system, it is said that people who were way behind the times or people who did not have ability to do so were sometimes called "Tenpo sen."

On the other hand, as one Tenpo-tsuho coin was converted as eight rin (one Kanei-tsuho coin was one rin) in the new monetary system, it is said that people who were way behind the times or people who did not have ability to do so were sometimes cynically called 'Tenpo sen.'

sen.j: 寛永通宝真鍮当四文銭の成功により銀座 (歴史)が潤ったことに対抗し、金座御金改約の後藤三右衛門の発案により高額の銭貨の発行へ至った。
sen.e: With the successful circualtion of Kanei-tsuho shimonsen coins, gin-za became affluent; in order to counterbalance this, Sanemon GOTO, okanearatameyaku of kin-za, proposed of issuing more coins of higher rates.

With the successful circualtion of Kanei-tsuho shimonsen coins, gin-za became affluent; in order to counterbalance this, Sanemon GOTO, okanearatameyaku of kin-za, proposed issuing more coins of higher rates.

Opposing the fact that the successful circulation of the Kanei-tsuho shinchu toshimonsen (bronze Kanrei-tsuho equivalent to four mon) made gin-za (an organization in charge of casting and appraising of silver during the Edo period) affluent, Sanemon GOTO, the Kin-za Okane aratame-yaku (an organizer of kin-za), proposed issuing more coins of higher rates.
sen.cmt: 用語、表現を変えました。

sen.j: このため天保通寳は金座主導で鋳造が行われることとなった。
sen.e: For this reason, Tenpo-tsuho coins came to be casted mainly at kin-za.
For this reason, Tenpo-tsuho coins came to be casted mainly at kin-za.
For this reason, the minting of the Tenpo-tsuho coin came to be led by the kin-za.

sen.j: 規定量目は五匁五分、規定品位は銅78%、鉛12%、スズ10%と定められたが、明治時代の造幣局の分析では銀0.037%、銅81.307%、鉛9.742%、錫8.261%、鉄0.056%、亜鉛0.193%、アンチモン0.035%、ヒ素0.182%、硫黄0.084%となっている。
sen.e: Its prescribed weight was 20.6 grams, its prescribed composition was 78% of copper, 12% of lead, 10% of tin, however, according to the analysis conducted by Japan Mint during the Meiji period, it was 0.037% of silver, 81.307% of copper, 9.742% of lead, 8.261% of tin, 0.056% of iron, 0.193% of zinc, 0.035% of antimony, 0.182% of arsenic, and 0.084% of sulfer.

Its prescribed weight was 20.6 grams, its prescribed composition was 78% of copper, 12% of lead, 10% of tin, however, according to the analysis conducted by Japan Mint during the Meiji period, it was 0.037% of silver, 81.307% of copper, 9.742% of lead, 8.261% of tin, 0.056% of iron, 0.193% of zinc, 0.035% of antimony, 0.182% of arsenic, and 0.084% of sulfer.

Its prescribed weight was 5 monme 5 bu (approximately 20.6 grams), its prescribed composition was 78 percents of copper, 12 percents of lead, 10 percents of tin; however, according to the analysis conducted by Japan Mint during the Meiji period, it was 0.037 percents of silver, 81.307 percents of copper, 9.742 percents of lead, 8.261 percents of tin, 0.056 percents of iron, 0.193 percents of zinc, 0.035 percents of antimony, 0.182 percents of arsenic, and 0.084 percents of sulfur.
sen.cmt: スペル、用語を変更しました。

sen.j: 天保6年（1835年）6月15日に鋳造が始まり同年9月2日より発行され、鋳造は翌7年（1836年）年12月に中断されるが、このときまでの鋳造高は29,710,700枚であった。
sen.e: The casting started on June 15, 1835 and the issuance on September 2 of the same year; the number of coins casted up until December 1836, the year when it was temporarily stopped, was 29,710,700.
The casting started on June 15, 1835 and was issued on September 2 of the same year; the number of coins casted up until December 1836, the year when it was temporarily stopped, was 29,710,700.
The minting started on July 10, 1835 and was issued on October 23 of the same year; the number of coins minted up until January 1837 when it was temporarily stopped was 29,710,700.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直しました。

sen.j: 8年（1837年）8月に再開され、13年（1842年）1月までの鋳造高は10,024,500枚で天保年間の合計は39,735,200枚とされる。
sen.e: The casting was restarted in August 1837, and the number of coins casted until 1842 was 10,024,500, and 39,735,200 during the Tenpo period.
Casting was restarted in August 1837, and the number of coins casted until 1842 was 10,024,500, and 39,735,200 during the Tenpo period.
Minting was restarted in August 1837, and the number of coins minted until February 1842 was 10,024,500; the total coins during Tenpo era was 39,735,200.

sen.j: 天保6年より13年までの総鋳造高を39,732,200枚とする記述もある。
sen.e: Some records say that the total of the coins casted between 1835 and 1842 was 39,732,200.
Some records say that the total of the coins casted between 1835 and 1842 was 39,732,200.
Some records say that the total of the coins minted between 1835 and 1842 was 39,732,200.

sen.j: 何れかが「五」と「二」の読み違いで誤植であることになる。
sen.e: It is thought this inconsistency was due to calculation erros caused by the misreading of "五 (five)" and "二 (two)."
It is thought this inconsistency was due to calculation errors caused by the misreading of "五 (five)" and "二 (two)."
It is thought this inconsistency was due to calculation errors caused by the misreading of '五' (five) and '二' (two).

sen.j: 天保年間の鋳造により江戸幕府が得た利益は180,800両である。
sen.e: The profit of the Edo bakufu gained by coin casting during the Tenpo period was 180,000 ryo.
The profit of the Edo bakufu gained by coin casting during the Tenpo period was 180,000 ryo.
The profit of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) gained by coin minting during the Tenpo era was 180,800 ryo.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせ、数字を原文に合わせました。

sen.j: 弘化4年（1847年）10月18日に鋳造が再開され、これ以降大幅に増鋳され万延年間に最盛期を迎えた。
sen.e: The casting was restarted on October 18, 1847; the number of casting was rapidly raised after that and it experienced its prime time during the Manen period.
The casting was restarted on October 18, 1847; the number of casting was rapidly raised after that and it experienced its prime during the Manen period.
After the minting was restarted on November 25, 1847, the number of minting was rapidly raised and it experienced its prime during the Manen era (1860 to 1861).
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直し、表現を変えました。

sen.j: 慶應元年（1865年）11月からは大坂難波に設置された銭座でも鋳造が始まり4年（1868年）1月まで行われ、大政奉還の後、新政府に設立された貨幣司は慶應4年（1868年）4月23日より明治3年（1870年）8月5日までに63,913,752枚を鋳造し、天保6年からの総鋳造高は484,804,054枚とされる。
sen.e: The casting was also started in gin-za of Osaka from November 1865 and continued until January 1868; after the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor), Kaheishi (a government office established by the new government) casted 63,913,752 coins from April 23, 1868 to August 5, 1870, and the total number of coins casted from 1835 went up to 484,804,054.

Casting was also started in gin-za of Osaka from November 1865 and continued until January 1868; after the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor), Kaheishi (a government office established by the new government) casted 63,913,752 coins from April 23, 1868 to August 5, 1870, and the total number of coins casted from 1835 went up to 484,804,054.

It was also minted in the gin-za located in Naniwa of Osaka from December 1865 to January 1868, and after the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor), Kaheishi (a government office taking over the kin-za and the gin-za) established by the new government minted 63,913,752 coins from May 15, 1868 to August 31, 1870; therefore the total number of coins minted from 1835 is said to be 484,804,054.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直し、用語を変更しました。

sen.j: 明和年間以降、寛永通宝鉄一文銭および真鍮四文銭の大量発行により銭相場は下落していたが、天保通寳の発行はこれに拍車をかけることになった。
sen.e: After 1763, the market price went down due to the mass production of kanei tsuho tetsu ichimonsen coins and shinchu shimonsen coins and the issuace of Tenpo- tsuho worsened the situation.
After 1763, the market price declined due to mass production of kanei tsuho tetsu ichimonsen coins and shinchu shimonsen coins and the issuace of Tenpo- tsuho only caused the situation to worsen.

After Meiwa era (1764 to 1771), as the market price declined due to mass production of the Kanei-tsuho tetsu ichimonsen (iron Kanei-tsuho equivalent to one mon) and the shinchu shimonsen coins, the issuance of Tenpo-tsuho only caused the situation to worsen.

sen.j: そこで幕府は銭相場の下落を防止するため、天保13年8月に御用相場として一両＝6500文の触書を出し、しばらくは一両＝6000～7000文程度で落ち着いたが、幕末期の大量発行に至り慶應年間にはついに一両＝10000文を突破した。
sen.e: Therefore, the Edo bakufu announced the furegaki (bakufu orders) to fix the rate to 6500 mon per ryo in order to prevent the downfall of the exchange rate and the rate stayed around 6000 to 7000 per ryo for a while, however, after the mass production, it went over 10000 mon per ryo.

Therefore, the Edo bakufu announced the furegaki (bakufu orders) to fix the rate to 6500 mon per ryo in order to prevent the downfall of the exchange rate and the rate stayed around 6000 to 7000 per ryo for a while, however, after the mass production, it went over 10000 mon per ryo.

Therefore, in order to prevent the downfall of the exchange rate of the sen (a unit of currency), the rate was officially fixed as 6,500 mon per ryo by the furegaki (bakufu orders) announced by the Edo bakufu in September 1842 to be stayed around 6,000 to 7,000 per ryo for a while, however, after the mass production in the end of the Edo period, it finally went over 10,000 mon per ryo in Keio era (1865 to 1868).
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「天保13年8月に」「幕末期」「慶應年間」を補足しました。

sen.j: また安政年間頃から寛永通寳銅一文銭、鉄一文銭、および真鍮四文銭などの通用において額面からの乖離が著しくなり、文久永宝の発行に至り相場は混乱し、文久2年（1862年）12月に幕府は改めて天保通寳を100文で通用させるよう通達を出したが、実際に100文銭としての通用は困難との申し出もあり、幕府は慶応元年（1865年）閏5月に、鉄一文銭＝1文および天保通寳＝100文の基準に対し以下のような増歩通用を認めざるを得なくなった。
sen.e: Furthermore, due to the circulation of kanei-tsuho ichimonsen coins, tetsu ichimonsen coins, and shinchu shimonsen coins, the gap between the face value became remarkable and the exchange market confused even after the issuance of bunkyu eiho; therefore, the Edo bakufu ordered to fix the rate of tenpo-tsuho by 100 mon, however, there was a report that this rate was impossible and the Edo bakufu had to accept the following rates with the standard of tetsu ichimonsen coin = 1 mon and Tenpo tsusen coin = 100 mon:

Furthermore, due to the circulation of kanei-tsuho ichimonsen coins, tetsu ichimonsen coins, and shinchu shimonsen coins, the gap between the face value became remarkable and the exchange market confused even after the issuance of bunkyu eiho; therefore, the Edo bakufu ordered to fix the rate of tenpo-tsuho by 100 mon, however, there was a report that this rate was impossible and the Edo bakufu had to accept the following rates with the standard of tetsu ichimonsen coin = 1 mon and Tenpo tsusen coin = 100 mon:

Furthermore, under the significant deviations from the face value since around Ansei era (1854 to 1859) in circulating the Kanei-tsuho do ichimonsen (copper Kanei-tsuho equivalent to one mon), the tetsu ichimonsen coins, and the shinchu shimonsen coins, and so on, the issuance of Bunkyu-eiho (a coin first minted in Bunkyu era [1854 to 1859]) brought the disorder of the exchange market; therefore in January 1863, the bakufu reordered to fix the rate of the Tenpo-tsuho by 100 mon, however, by reports that this rate was impossible and others, in June 1865, the Edo bakufu had to accept to circulate it by the fair market price not by the face value as follows with the standard of the tetsu ichimonsen coin equivalent to one mon and the Tenpo-tsuho equivalent to 100 mon:
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「安政年間頃から」「文久2年（1862年）12月」「慶応元年（1865年）閏5月に」を補足し、表現を変えました。

sen.j: 寛永通寳文銭および耳白銭：6文
sen.e: Kanei-tsuho monsen and Mimishiro zeni coins: 6 mon
Kanei-tsuho monsen and Mimishiro zeni coins: 6 mon
Kanei-tsuho monsen and Mimijirozeni (one mon coin issued by the Tokugawa shogunate in 1714): 6 mon

sen.j: その他寛永通寳銅一文銭：4文
sen.e: Other Kanei-tsuho do ichimonsen coin: 4 mon
Other Kanei-tsuho do ichimonsen coin: 4 mon
Other Kanei-tsuho do ichimonsen coin: 4 mon

sen.j: 寛永通寳真鍮四文銭：12文
sen.e: Kanei-tsuho shinchu shimonsen coin: 12 mon
Kanei-tsuho shinchu shimonsen coin: 12 mon
Kanei-tsuho shinchu shimonsen coin: 12 mon

sen.j: 文久永寳四文銭：8文
sen.e: Bunkyu-eiho shimonsen coin: 8 mon
Bunkyu-eiho shimonsen coin: 8 mon
Bunkyu-eiho shimonsen coin: 8 mon

sen.j: 公鋳のものには「長郭」、「細郭」、「中郭」、「広郭」といった手代わりが知られており、「長郭」は「寳」字の「貝」がやや縦長で郭も僅かに縦長の長方形である。
sen.e: Among the officially casted coins, ones with "long kaku (frame surrounding the hole of the coin)," "thin kaku," "middle kaku," "wide kaku," are well known. "Long kaku" has slighly longer "寳"and kaku.

Among the officially casted coins, ones with "long kaku (frame surrounding the hole of the coin)," "thin kaku," "middle kaku," "wide kaku," are well known. "Long kaku" has a slightly longer "寳"and kaku.

Among the officially minted coins, the different styles are known such as one with 'Chokaku' (long framed surrounding the hole of a coin), 'Saikaku' (thin frame), 'Chukaku' (standard frame), 'Kokaku' (wide frame) and 'Chokaku' has a slightly longer '貝,' the part of the Chinese character '寳,' as well as the rectangle frame surrounding the hole.

sen.j: 他の三種は「貝」が横広でほぼ字体も同一で郭はほぼ正方形であり、郭の幅により分類されているが中間的なものも存在し、制作上の移行期のものと考えられる。
sen.e: All other three types of coins have wider "貝" with similar styles of writing and the holes in the center are square shaped; therefore, they are categorized by the width of kaku, but some of them cannot be clearly categorized into one of them and are considered to have been made during the stage of transition of one type to another.

The otherr three types of coins have wider "貝" with similar styles of writing and the holes in the center are square shaped; therefore, they are categorized by the width of kaku, but some of them cannot be clearly categorized and are considered to have been made during the stage of transition from one type to another.

The other three types of coins have wider '貝' with similar styles of writing and the holes in the center are square shaped; therefore, they are categorized by the width of kaku (frame surrounding the hole of a coin), but some of them cannot be clearly categorized and are considered to have been made during the stage of transition from one type to another.
sen.cmt: スペル、表記を変えました。

sen.j: 貨幣収集界には天保6年から翌年鋳造分を「長郭」あるいは「中郭」、8年から13年までのものを「細郭」、弘化4年以降のものを「広郭」とする説もあったが、これでは現存数と鋳造数の比率に整合しないとの説もある。
sen.e: Some of the coin collectors claimed that coins casted between 1835 and 1836 were "long kaku" or "middle kaku," and the coins casted between 1837 and 1842 were "thin kaku," and the coins casted after 1844 were "wide kaku," but some argue that this categorization does not match the ratio of the number of existing coins and coins casted.

Some coin collectors claimed that coins cast between 1835 and 1836 were "long kaku" or "middle kaku," and the coins casted between 1837 and 1842 were "thin kaku," and the coins cast after 1844 were "wide kaku," but some argue that this categorization does not match the ratio of the number of existing coins and coins casted.

In the world of collecting coins, a opinion that claimed that coins minted between 1835 and the following year were called 'Chokaku' or 'Chukaku,' those between 1837 and 1842 were 'Saikaku,' and those after 1847 were 'Kokaku,' but the other argued that this categorization did not match the ratio of the number of existing coins and coins minted.

sen.j: いずれにしても「長郭」が初期のもので、「広郭」が後期のものであるとする説は定着している。
sen.e: In any case, it is agreed that "long kaku" coins were the ones produced during the early Tenpo period and "wide kaku" coins were produced around the end of the Ten[po period.
In any case, it is agreed that "long kaku" coins were the ones produced during the early Tenpo period and "wide kaku" coins were produced around the end of the Tenpo period.
In any case, it is agreed that 'Chokaku' coins were produced during the early period and 'Kokaku' were the late period.

tit.e: Coins casted secretly in local areas
Coins cast secretly in local areas
Coins cast secretly in local areas

sen.j: 天保通寳は寛永通寳5～6枚分の量目に過ぎず、吹き減りおよび工賃を差し引いても一枚10文前後のコストで製造可能である為、幕府は地方での発行を「禁制」として認めなかったが、幕末期に偽装工作としての地方貨幣発行の陰で各藩による密鋳が横行した。
sen.e: Tenpo-tsuho only weighed 5 or 6 Kanei-tshuho coins, and it was possible to produce a coin in 10 mon; therefore, even if the Edo bakufu did not admit coinage in local areas, some domains secretly produced imitation coins together with local coin casting organizations.

Tenpo-tsuho only weighed 5 or 6 Kanei-tshuho coins, and it was possible to produce a coin in 10 mon; therefore, even if the Edo bakufu did not admit coinage in local areas, some domains secretly produced imitation coins together with local coin casting organizations.

Since the Tenpo-tsuho only weighed five or six Kanei-tsuho coins and it was possible to produce a coin in 10 mon even less labor charge and reducing the weight by minting, the bakufu did not admit to issue the coin in local areas as 'Kinsei' (taboo), however some clans secretly minted the Tenpo-tsuho behind the imitative deception of the local coin issuance in the end of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「吹き減りおよび工賃を差し引いても」「幕末期に」「偽装工作としての」を補足しました。

sen.j: 明治時代に引換回収された天保通寳は5億8674万枚にも上り、これは金座および貨幣司が鋳造したものを1億枚以上も上回る数であり、かつ流通高のすべてが回収されたわけではないため、密鋳は2億枚程度に達したものと思われる。
sen.e: Tenpo-tsuho coins immobilized and exchanged during the Meiji period totalled 586,740,000; as this amount is 1000 million more coins than those casted at kin-za and kaheishi and as it is thought that not all the Tenpo tsuho coins were immoblized, the number of coins secretly casted is thought the be around 2000 millions.

Tenpo-tsuho coins immobilized and exchanged during the Meiji period totalled 586,740,000; as this amount is 100 million more coins than those casted at kin-za and kaheishi and as it is thought that not all the Tenpo tsuho coins were immoblized, the number of coins secretly cast is thought the be around 200 million.

The Tenpo-tsuho coins immobilized and exchanged during the Meiji period totaled 586,740,000 which is 100 million more coins than those minted at the kin-za and the Kaheishi, and considering not all the Tenpo-tsuho coins were immobilized, the number of coins secretly minted is thought the be around 200 million.

sen.j: 密鋳に関わった藩は判明しているだけでも水戸藩、久留米藩、薩摩藩、福岡藩、岡藩、土佐藩、長州藩、会津藩、仙台藩、久保田藩、盛岡藩など10を超える。
sen.e: At least more than 10 domains have been found to have been involved in the secret casting: the Mito domain, Kurume domain, Satsuma domain, Fukuoka domain, Oka domain, Tosa domain, Choshu domain, Aizu domain, Sendai domain, Kubota domain, and Morioka domain.

At least more than 10 domains have been found to have been involved in the secret casting: the Mito domain, Kurume domain, Satsuma domain, Fukuoka domain, Oka domain, Tosa domain, Choshu domain, Aizu domain, Sendai domain, Kubota domain, and Morioka domain.
The clans involved in the secret minting were more than following 10 clans which have been found: Mito, Kurume, Satsuma, Fukuoka, Oka, Tosa, Choshu, Aizu, Sendai, Kubota, and Morioka clans.

sen.j: そればかりでなく、素性の不明ないわゆる「不知銭（ふちせん）」とされる天保通寳も多種存在し、現在のところ判明していない他の藩によるもの、あるいは小規模な民鋳によるものなどが考えられる。
sen.e: There are also many kinds of Tenpo-tsuho coins which origins are not clear (called fusechin); they are thought to be produced by unknown domains or small private casting organizations.
There are also many kinds of Tenpo-tsuho coins whose origins are not clear (called fusechin); they are thought to have been produced by unknown domains or small private casting organizations.
There are also many kinds of the Tenpo-tsuho coins whose origins were not clear called 'Fuchisen;' they are thought to have been produced by unknown clans or small private casting organizations.
sen.cmt: 表記、用語を変更しました。
